title: Human-in-the-Loop: Where Agents Must Stop and Ask
intent: Understand where and why an agent must defer to a human, and how to design clear handoff points.

core_idea.one_liner: Autonomy without checkpoints is a liability.
why_it_matters: Some decisions are contextual, political, or risky.
Humans provide accountability, not just intelligence.
Well-placed handoffs increase trust and adoption.

definition.human_in_the_loop: A mandatory pause where the agent presents its findings or plan and waits for human approval or input.

handoff_patterns.description: Agent proposes a plan and waits for approval before execution.
Agent suggests a decision with pros/cons; human selects.
Agent stops when encountering undefined or forbidden cases.

micro_example.scenario: Agent identifies need to correct master data values.

agent_output.proposal: Apply value mapping fix to 1,200 records.

guards: Agent must not proceed without approval.

teach_it_in_english.simple_explanation: The agent knows when to stop and ask for permission.
teach_it_in_english.one_sentence_definition: Human-in-the-loop is how responsibility stays human.

practical_checklist: Does the agent resume correctly after approval?
